title.value: A*Net: A Scalable Path-based Reasoning Approach for Knowledge Graphs
title.justification: The title is mentioned at the top of the provided text.
title.quote: A*Net: A Scalable Path-based Reasoning Approach for Knowledge Graphs

extractions.description: This paper introduces A*Net, a scalable path-based method for reasoning on large-scale knowledge graphs. It leverages the A* algorithm to learn a priority function that selects important nodes and edges during iterations, significantly reducing time and memory footprint in both training and inference. Empirical results on various benchmarks demonstrate A*Net's competitive performance and its ability to handle million-scale datasets efficiently.

type.justification: This paper provides empirical results on various benchmarks to demonstrate the performance and efficiency of A*Net.
type.quote: Experiments on both transductive and inductive knowledge graph reasoning benchmarks show that A*Net achieves competitive performance with existing state-of-the-art path-based methods.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on reasoning methods for knowledge graphs.
name.quote: Our A*Net learns a priority function to select important nodes and edges at each iteration, to reduce time and memory footprint for both training and inference.

name.justification: The paper leverages neural networks for the priority function in the A* algorithm, which is a central component in Graph Neural Networks.
name.quote: Instead, we design a neural priority function based on the node representations at the current iteration, which can be end-to-end trained by the objective function of the reasoning task without any additional supervision.

name.justification: The paper focuses on scaling path-based methods for large-scale knowledge graphs, which is a key aspect of scalable machine learning.
name.quote: To verify the scalability of our method, we also evaluate A*Net on ogbl-wikikg2, a million-scale knowledge graph that is 2 magnitudes larger than datasets solved by previous path-based methods.

name.justification: The name of the proposed model is A*Net, which is the main focus of the paper.
name.quote: Here we present A*Net, a scalable path-based method for knowledge graph reasoning.

is_contributed.justification: A*Net is introduced as a novel method in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: Here we present A*Net, a scalable path-based method for knowledge graph reasoning.

is_executed.justification: The experiments were conducted using GPUs.
is_executed.quote: Figure 1: Validation MRR w.r.t. training time on ogbl-wikikg2 (1 A100 GPU).

is_compared.justification: A*Net is compared against various existing models such as embedding methods and NBFNet.
is_compared.quote: Experiments on both transductive and inductive knowledge graph reasoning benchmarks show that A*Net achieves competitive performance with existing state-of-the-art path-based methods.

referenced_paper_title.justification: A*Net is a novel contribution of this paper, hence it is not referenced from any other prior work.

name.justification: RotatE is used as a baseline for comparison in the experiments.
name.quote: Tab. 1 shows that A*Net outperforms all embedding methods and GNNs, and is on par with NBFNet on transductive knowledge graph reasoning.

is_contributed.justification: RotatE is used as a baseline model and not contributed by this paper.
is_contributed.quote: Tab. 1 shows that A*Net outperforms all embedding methods and GNNs, and is on par with NBFNet on transductive knowledge graph reasoning.

is_executed.justification: Experiments involving RotatE were executed to compare its performance with A*Net.
is_executed.quote: Tab. 1 shows that A*Net outperforms all embedding methods and GNNs, and is on par with NBFNet on transductive knowledge graph reasoning.

referenced_paper_title.quote: Complex embeddings for simple link prediction

name.justification: NBFNet is used as a baseline for comparison in the experiments.
name.quote: We compare A*Net against embedding methods, GNNs and path-based methods. The embedding methods are TransE [6], ComplEx [42], RotatE [38], HAKE [55], RotH [7], PairRE [8], ComplEx+Relation Prediction [12] and ConE [3]. The GNNs are RGCN [36], CompGCN [43] and GraIL [39]. The path-based methods are MINERVA [14], Multi-Hop [29], CURL [52], NeuralLP [50], DRUM [35], NBFNet [58] and RED-GNN [54].

is_contributed.justification: NBFNet is used as a baseline model and not contributed by this paper.
is_contributed.quote: Tab. 1 shows that A*Net outperforms all embedding methods and GNNs, and is on par with NBFNet on transductive knowledge graph reasoning.

is_executed.justification: Experiments involving NBFNet were executed to compare its performance with A*Net.
is_executed.quote: Tab. 1 shows that A*Net outperforms all embedding methods and GNNs, and is on par with NBFNet on transductive knowledge graph reasoning.

is_compared.justification: NBFNet is compared with A*Net in the performance evaluation.
is_compared.quote: Tab. 1 shows that A*Net outperforms all embedding methods and GNNs, and is on par with NBFNet on transductive knowledge graph reasoning.
